column49: his eye's closed; a pair of old ladies gab in profile (plate 27); a blue collar guy gets caught up
column50: ethusiastically reading his Daily Mirror (31); a prim and properly dressed elderly woman finds something on the train quite un-prim and improper to laugh out loud at (34); a man yawns
column51: his mouth wide open (44); a pin-up girl on the Chesterfield cigarette placard slyly peers over a sailor's shoulder
column52: betraying him as more lonely than alone (83); an accordion player ambles between the rows of passengers
column53: singing his song
column54: his eyes closed and oblivious to the passengers' aloofness (89).  In 2002
column55: the great landscape photographer Ansel Adams had his birthday celebrated from beyond his grave by all sorts of his hangers-on
column56: the usual crowds from the Sierra Club
column57: the Yosemite workshops and PBS. It was a fitting tribute
column58: a larger-than-life gushing forth of accolades and genuflection that would have pleased the professional publicity seeking cameraman.  The next year
column59: however
column60: marked the centenary of another great photographer
column62: there was little fanfare. This was also quite fitting
column64: this quiet and fastidious man has probably had an influence greater than any other on the photography of the past 50 years.  In contrast to the bigger-than-a-breadbox boxed edition of "Ansel Adams at 100
column65: there was no Walker Evans at 100" released in 2003. However
column66: this belated volume is a most fitting volume to the greatest photographic collector of prosaic American ephemera. In 89 plates
column67: Evans created a revolution in documentary photography. Seeking not to convince
column70: he  achieves that rarest and most precious of photographic aspirations: He permits the world to simply see the world as he has seen it through his own eyes.   There's nothing necessarily novel about that in itself. Yet
column71: what makes this work so singular and powerful is that we not only see through Evans' eyes
column73: are moved by it and what we've seen is indelibly imprinted within our minds' eyes.  Anybody can make such miracles of nature as Momument Valley
column74: the Grand Tetons or Half-dome at Yosemite beautiful. Walker Evans
column77: and raised it to something unique and profound through his taste

column1: I honestly wasn't expecting too much from this book when I originally looked at it. I was expecting the caliber of the not-so-"Complete" series... Boy
column2: did that get shot in the foot. This is probably one of the best supplements released in the past three years. It's very comprehensive with very little useless
column3: extraneous information and is organized well. The sections written to be helpful to the DM are actually helpful to the DM- not just a bunch of 'no duh
column4: ' common sense information like many of the other new supplements. The new classes are actually interesting- not merely spinoffs or mixes of other classes
column5: and the Taint tables offer a really interesting new idea. The new creatures are also very intriguing
column6: again
column7: not just spinoffs. Take the Grey Jester: a humanoid that basically eats the laughter and happiness out of peoples (and PCs) to create mindless drones to do its bidding. There is also a little speckling of possible mini-adventures that help you get an idea of how to employ the concepts introduced into a campaign. While the book is really designed for a horror-oriented campaign
column8: it would be very easy to adapt some of these ideas into a brief adventure
column9: even just one dungeon. Pages and pages aren't wasted on new magic items or overly extensive info on adaptation into Ebberon
column10: Faerun
column11: etc. There's just the right about of info on both.  It would be worth the money for a one-shot Halloween adventure. It's very original
column12: very creative
column13: and a great buy. It would be a perfect match for anyone intending to run a Ravenloft campaign

column1: In a sense
column2: this book is a mirror to the problems covered in Wittgenstein's "Philosophical Investigations"--albeit with tighter arguments and far less meandering than Wittgenstein's groundbreaking work (this was published three years before Wittgenstein's posthumous PI). Both men were dedicated to freeing philosophy from what Ryle terms "category errors"--misapplications of the ordinary referential scope of a given term ("mind" as a  concept which must necessarily oppose "substance" for instance--this duality forces us to ascribe and essentialize qualities to the incorporeal along the same lines as that of substance
column3: by giving it attributes on the linguistic model of physical objects) These misapplications have led philosophers into vast problems which
column4: by their very nature as linguistic misuses
column5: are unsolvable (but not dis-solvable). Parts of it will provoke cries of "behaviorism!"
column6: but Ryle included a chapter near the end distancing his stance from Skinner et al. (how well he manages in this is debatable!) Brilliant
column7: straightforward
column8: and elegant
column9: this is one the best works of 20th-century philosophy

column2: and unfortunately sad story about Indian life on the great plains.  The book seems very well researched and therefore more interesting to read since it is about history.  The Indians suffered strategically from a lack of organization
column3: but their whole life style was about independence and in fact a much more pure form of democracy in selecting and de-selecting their leaders.  In reading the story with regard to the lies and deceipt of the white men it reminded me that world politics and war is no different today than then.  Crazy Horse had attributes that leaders should aspire to
column4: he wanted to help his people and he was not vain about himself as leader.  In the end he was tricked into surrender by his own people.  I thought it was one of the best books of Indian life and history that I have read

column1: I grew up reading Pauline Kael's reviews
column2: mostly by walking to the public library in the small town where I grew up -- I'd snag the New Yorker off the shelf and immerse myself in what she had to say about movies
column3: many of which would never come to my town.  But I was enthralled.    I love her reviews now for the same reason I loved them then -- she makes me want to see the movies she writes about.  And more than that
column4: she makes me want to see movies
column5: period.  Her passion for the medium -- even when she doesn't like a film -- is contagious
column6: and she expresses it beautifully.    Surprisingly to me
column7: in these early reviews she frequently quotes the reviews of other critics and then mercilessly takes apart what they have said.  She particularly has it in for the New York Times' Bosley Crowther
column8: but she doesn't let others off the hook easily
column9: either.    Kael is fun to read
column10: even if you haven't seen the movie she is talking about.  I've never seen "The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone"
column11: though I have seen "Suddenly Last Summer" -- both based on works of Tennessee Williams.  But Kael's 1961 review of "Mrs. Stone" is a hilarious read.  In one part
column12: she says:    "The men who filmed 'The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone' seem to think the idea of an aging woman seeking companionship and love so daring and unusual that they fumble around with it almost as much as the doctor in the screen version of 'Suddenly
column13: Last Summer'
column14: who couldn't seem to cope with the simple facts of Sebastian's homosexuality and kept saying
column15: 'You DON'T mean THAT?'-- 'No
column16: it CAN'T be THAT?' -- 'WHAT are you saying?' -- 'What do you MEAN?'  I assumed the youngest child in the audience would get the point before he did.  By trying so diligently to make Mrs. Stone so sympathetic and understandable the director and writer
column17: Jose Quintero and Gavin Lambert
column18: kill all interest in her.  We could accept a woman buying love
column19: but why make her haggle over it?"    Kael is hilarious
column20: maddening
column21: and most of all
column22: thought-provoking.  And if you love movies
column23: she'll make you love them more.

column2: you'll only  be lying to yourself. And
column3: according to advice given in DAVE BARRY'S MONEY SECRETS (from which this question was taken)
column4: "The place to lie in on your federal tax return."  This is a very funny guide that spoofs much of the personal financial advice that can be found in other books
column5: TV shows and online . . . save your money on them; buy this one  instead . . . you may not get rich if you do
column6: but you will certainly laugh a lot.  Barry has previously written on such other topics as politics
column7: fitness and parenting . . . I enjoyed those
column8: but this latest one may well be his very best--especially because it will make you wonder why  people behave the way they do when it comes to money.  For example
column9: in the above quiz
column10: he states
column11: "That if your answers are all threes [on all the questions]
column12: be advised that we're having a minor technical problem calculating your score because of  Nigerian red tape. To smooth things out
column13: we need you to send us an 'advance fee' of $5
column15: which you will get back many times over."  The amazing thing is that many people do just that!  There were many other hilarious tidbits; among them: * Many children learn about money by starting their own businesses
column16: the classic example being the sidewalk lemonade stand. This is an opportunity to teach your child fundamental economic principles. I'm not suggesting that you encourage your child to have a lemonade stand; that's WAY too much work. I'm suggesting that you explain to your child that if he buys lemonade from some other kid's stand
column17: and then happens to choke on a lemon seed
column18: they you would be in a position to sue the other kid's parents for thousands of dollars. That is what I mean by "fundamental economic principles."  * One way to take money is in the form of traveler's checks. The way these work is
column19: you give a traveler's check company a bunch of money
column20: and the traveler's check company gives you some checks. You cash some of these checks on your trip
column21: and when you get home you put the rest of them in the back of your sock drawer for safekeeping
column22: and then you forget all about them. Eventually you die
column23: and the traveler's check company gets to keep the money you paid for the uncashed checks forever.  And this final one that--while presented in a humorous fashion--makes much sense at least to me:  *Presidential Election Campaign Fund checkoff box: If you check this box
column24: $3 of your taxes will be earmarked for a special fund to pay for presidential campaigns. Notice that the government does not permit you to earmark money for poor people
column25: or sick people
column26: or national defense. No
column27: the government permits you to earmark money only  for the purpose of enabling politicians to produce TV commercials designed to appeal to voters who have the IQ of a Vienna sausage. To make matters worse
column28: some of this federal campaign money goes to candidates who have about as much chance of getting elected president as SpongeBob SquarePants. In 2004
column29: of example
column30: more than $800
column31: 000 of earmarked U.S. taxpayer dollars went to Lyndon LaRouche
column32: a convicted felon and complete space loon who has been running for president since 1980
column33: and who has claimed
column34: among other things
column35: that Walter Mondale was a Soviet agent and Queen Elizabeth II is a drug dealer. If you check the Presidential Election Campaign Fund box
column36: it won't affect the amount of tax you owe
column37: but I will lose all respect for you.

column1: This book is about the author
column2: a Mid westerner
column3: travelling  to Mississippi to learn more about the state where his people came from.  It is extremely well done.  The author travels around the state
column4: interviews many prominent and not-as-prominent Mississippians about problems
column5: solutions
column6: and opportunites for the state to move beyond its history of severe racial problems. In the process he summarizes a lot of history
column7: and introduces many insights about how Mississippi got where it is and what it needs to do to move on.  One thing I
column8: as a white Mississippian with a somewhat liberal bent
column9: found refreshing was his not falling into the trap that many of us Mississippians do of saying that all of that stuff is old news and we have moved beyond it.  Things are undoubtedly better now than before
column10: but while segregation may not be legal it is still very alive in the hearts and minds of the residents
column11: both black and white If books like Walton's cause us to reexamine some of our "truths" about the state
column12: it will have served an extremely useful purpose.  At any rate
column13: for one wanting to understand more about Mississippi
column14: reading this book is a good way to do it.

column1: I've never really been a big fan of Lucinda but wanted to give this Fillmore release a chance.  Glad I did.    She delivers each song from the soul and she's surrounded by a great band.  I won't say this is a lot of fun to listen to - you sort of go through experiences with her - but she may be one of the best story tellers out there and each of these performances tells us a little more about this fantastic singer.  And for those who haven't listened to much of her music this isn't straight country.  There are jazz and rock sounds going on here.  This is a nice release that's well worth the money

column1: David Rusk
column2: former mayor of Albuquerque
column3: NM
column4: puts his experience and research to work in this compelling report.  In it
column5: he connects the economic and practical success of America's urban centers with the degree  of socioeconomic and racial segregation present in each.   The result is a  blueprint that local
column6: state and federal officials can use to reverse the  troubling trends in our cities.  Specifically
column7: he calls for metro-wide  planning councils
column8: city-county consolidation
column9: aggressive annexation by  older central cities
column10: and changes to state and federal laws to create   unified cities without suburbs. The text also includes numerous interesting  case studies that demonstrate what
column11: when practiced
column12: his ideas are capable  of. Easy-to-read
column13: fascinating
column14: and enlightening.  David Rusk is talking.   Are America's city officials listening

If you are seeking to better understand Scripture...this book is a MUST
If you live in a city without English in its bookstores
column2: what do you read? Well
column3: odds are you encounter a Westerner from time to time and exchange books you've read for books you haven't. You never know what you'll wind up with. It's Book Crossing
column4: taken to a much higher level.   And so it was that I found myself looking at a battered copy of MORGAN'S PASSING
column5: with no memory of who gave it to me or what book(s) I gave up in return. Pages brown and falling out

column8: a desperate junkie in need of my reading fix
column9: I gave it a shot.   And
column10: at last
column11: the review. I thoroughly enjoyed this book. The story of how I obtained it is much like the character of Morgan himself. He just kind of appears -- you don't know why -- but you're glad you met the memorable eccentric. This book is witty
column12: original
column13: and well worth reading. Ignore the [...] on the cover about "the love story." The book has one
column14: but it's incidental. Some marketing bozo didn't know how to describe true creativity.   Okay
column15: time to go broke ordering more Anne Tyler books from Amazon. All the way from China. There's even a Putlizer Prize winner in there.

column1: In reading and reviewing two of Bernard Lewis's recent books (What Went Wrong? Western Impact and Middle Eastern Response 2002 and The Crisis of Islam: Holy War and Holy Terror 2003) I was favorably impressed with not only his obvious erudition
column2: but with his reasoned tone and his realistic perceptions.  However
column3: in this volume
column4: which is a collection of some of his writings going back to the 1950s
column5: I found myself a bit mystified.  On the one hand there is the brilliance and eloquence for which the venerable historian is well known.  On the other hand
column6: there are some strange and unsettled statements which lead me to wonder if Professor Lewis has not lost some of his fabled acuity.  First
column7: there is the inclusion of a very short piece entitled "We Must Be Clear" that he wrote for the Washington Post a few days after September 11
column8: 2001 in which he is anything but.  Apparently Lewis wants the US to be clear about its intentions in the Middle East in light of the terrorist attacks on 9/11.  He concludes that "What is needed is clarity in recognizing issues and alignments
column9: firmness and determination in defining and applying policy." (p. 370)  What this vague and essentially empty pronouncement follows is Lewis's apprehension that some states are "friends" on two levels
column10: one "a deep mutual commitment" and the other "based on a perception of shared interests." (p. 369-370)  One will permit me a "You don't say?" here.  In this same piece Lewis mentions that Saddam Hussein "has made war against three of his neighbors..." and that the other states in the Middle East "are neither forgetful of the past nor confident of the future."  What Saddam Hussein (and what his neighbors think about him) has to do with 9/11 is unclear.  It's as if Lewis had something he wanted to say
column11: some connection he wanted to draw
column12: but was unable to be clear about it
column13: perhaps for political reasons or because he thought he knew something he wasn't at liberty to share.  At any rate
column14: even more disconcerting is the article entitled "A Time for Toppling" from the Wall Street Journal a year later (September 26
column15: 2002) in which he seems to be a stalking horse for Bush's desire to invade Iraq.  He doesn't however argue so much that Saddam Hussein is a danger to the US
column16: but instead makes the claim that in order to solve the Palestinian/Israeli conflict
column17: it is first necessary to deal with Saddam.  There is some legitimacy to this argument
column18: and Lewis recalls Saddam's policy of rewarding the families of Palestinian suicide bombers with stipends of $10
column20: 000.  However what is grievously wrongheaded about this "toppling" that Lewis seems unaware of--as was Bush and the neocons in the White House--is that in invading Iraq
column21: the US would create massively more problems than it would solve
column22: and would only exacerbate the predicament of the Israeli and Palestinian people
column23: since the Arab and Muslim world would rally around a kindred Muslim nation invaded by a foreign power even if it was the fiefdom of a hated dictator.  I am surprised that the usually wise and learned Professor Lewis could write so nakedly in favor of the foolishly aggressive policy of the Bush administration.  Personally
column24: I think Lewis revealed here the true heart of the historian: such a person may be incredibly wise and reasonable when he has time to think and rethink an issue and has the benefit of his research and a considerable experience; however when he is called upon to make a quick judgment on events still warm in the doing
column25: his judgment may suffer.  So let me recall the Bernard Lewis of the volumes mentioned above and let me quote from a couple of places in this collection in order to balance what would be
column26: on the basis of these two articles
column27: a misconception of the man.  Consider
column28: for example
column29: this statement on the three Abrahamic religions of the Middle East: "If we look at them in a wider global perspective
column30: Judaism
column31: Christianity and Islam are different branches of the same religion....Compared with the religions of India
column32: of China and of other places
column33: they are as alike as peas in a pod."  Lewis goes on to make the point that when Muslim and Christian say to one another
column34: "'You are an infidel and you will burn in hell
column35: ' they understand each other perfectly."  However "Such an argument between a Christian or a Muslim on the one side and a Buddhist or a Hindu on the other" would have been "impossible" because "They would not have known what they were talking about." (pp. 200-201)  This insight is from his essay "A Taxonomy of Group Hatred" which originally appeared in the Viennese review Transit in 1998-1999.  This is a particularly good essay (published in English here for the first time) in which Lewis doesn't mince words about the human failing called hatred and gives a most interesting psychological and historical take on this most destructive emotion which he allies lamentably with the very essence of the human process of self-identity.  He notes
column36: "Loyalty to the tribe
column37: however defined
column38: and hatred of other tribes are at the very core of identity." (p. 203)  There are 51 essays arranged in three parts
column39: "Past History
column40: Current History
column41: and About History."  There are pieces on such diverse subjects as money
column42: travel and food in addition to the usual political concerns of historians.  Particularly good
column43: because of the insight it affords us into the life of Bernard Lewis
column44: is the Introduction in which he outlines his career as a Middle Eastern historian.  I recommend this book for readers who want to increase their knowledge of the Middle East.  Here is Lewis's own justification for such a study: "The history of Islam is a vital and essential part of human history without which even 'our' own history is not fully intelligible." (p. 412

column1: Authors Brian E. Becker
column2: Mark A. Huselid and Dave Ulrich teach human resources (HR) executives that everything their departments do can influence their companies' profits - but not just in terms of their administrative actions. HR can have a meaningful impact on the corporation by developing employees' in-depth awareness of the business
column3: studying the drivers that generate the employee behaviors that move the company's strategy forward and establishing a new core competency model for HR professionals. We strongly recommend this book as essential for HR executives - and as an illuminating text for other corporate leaders
column4: right up to CEOs. While your company's HR department may already measure performance
column5: chances are those measurements don't evaluate the real dollars-and-cents impact on the bottom line. In fact
column6: this book shows how to determine what to measure with your HR Scorecard
column7: how to measure it and how to report back in fiscal terms that upper management can appreciate. This is an affirmation and a roadmap for everyone who ever wanted to prove that HR
column8: strategically deployed
column9: can significantly influence a company's performance and profitability

column1: Col. Hammes has taken the original thesis of "we make war the way we make money" presented by the Toffler's in "War and Anti-War" and fleshed it out with real examples. He provides a useful background of he various "generations" of war or the evolutions that war has made as economy and cultures have changed
column2: moves on to a description of Fourth Generation warfare (4GW) and then provides detailed examples including present date. It's important to understand that although this book is about 4GW or insurgency warfare
column3: it is also about the direction warfare is taking. The United States must be ready for conflicts that span the spectrum from 2GW to what will become 5GW. 4GW is like any insurgency...it requires lots of human skill
column4: good communications
column5: and interagency support...and something that Americans are not known for....patience. If you are a soldier interested in insurgency and how it is evolving this is a MUST READ book. If you are a civilian you'd better read this book if you want to understand how the world is unfolding around you. This book gets Mike Barr's 6 Star Rating

column1: I hate to admit it...especially because all the other reviewers have raved about it...but I find Truth and Method to be a real slog. Yes -- there is some good stuff here. But be warned - you will really

This book is brilliant. But I think it is very interesting that all the reviewers have such high praise for a text that is so very difficult. Great ideas do not need to be inaccessible. column1: The Loyalty Effect is an analysis of the effects of loyalty.  The author
column2: Frederick F. Reichheld
column3: takes a rigorous looks at a variety of successful companies and finds that those "that earned superior levels of customer loyalty and retention also earned consistently higher profits" and sustainable levels of growth.  The examples and data shown in this book give a clear picture of how loyalty can be earned through strong value creation and why this leads to long-term profitability and growth.  Beyond customer loyalty
column4: the author also looks at how the right employees
column5: the right investors and the right partnerships can add to the overall strength of a company.  The evidence that Reichheld presents in support of loyalty-based management is thought provoking and compelling.  While the author himself doesn't proclaim this that style of management is a magic "cure all"
column6: Reichheld's argument is extremely convincing and the research supporting his claim is clear: loyalty makes good economic sense.  People running businesses
column7: big and small
column8: can benefit from the ideas presented in The Loyalty Effect.  I highly recommend this book.

column1: I have learned more about Linear Algebra from this single book than all my other assorted (and fairly expensive!) texbooks combined; and
column2: for that matter
column3: more than my college class on the subject too. I'm now studying Differential Geometry and I always have this book nearby (in addition to two other Shaum's Outlines: that of Vector Analysis and Differential Geometry). Every textbook has something to offer - at least I usually give them the benefit of the doubt ;-). But for gaining a "working knowledge" of abstract mathematical concepts
column4: there's nothing so enlightening than studying the details of problem solving performed with delightful clarity by an expert in the field. In this book you can become the apprentice to Seymour Lipschutz as he reveals the mysteries that often form clouds in the minds of students of Linear Algebra.  Frequently
column5: when working in this text
column6: I would suddenly understand something that seemed so complex or obscure in my other LA texts. Actually
column7: I could then see what those other texts were attempting to convey but because of their particular styles
column8: they were just a bit "pedagogically challenged" :-)  Anyway
column9: for me
column10: this book is worth more than any pricey textbook on the subject. Just buy it and use it! You'll begin to see how cool Linear Algebra really is. Beware - mathematics at this level and beyond can be very addictive!  DH

column1: To review this book at length would ignore its lessons. My only advice is to read it and discover the Dogen for yourself.  You might come away thinking he's an idiot. He'd say he'd succeeded mightily in your education.
Leopold von Sacher-Masoch manages to illustrate a deep sexual fantasy and moralize at the same time.  The author artfully shows the reader the pain endured by Severin
column2: the main character
column3: and the twisted pleasure obtained from it.  The obsession over furs is just one aspect of his pain-pleasure complex.  It seems that von Sacher-Masoch
column4: like Sade
column5: oversimplifies complex feelings through autobiographical characters.  However
column6: unlike Sade's de Franval
column7: the main character seems open to the possibility that this "deviant behavior" isn't perfection
column8: but the manifestation of a personal problem dealt with in an unhealthy way. He seems to have enough of an open mind to "learn."  I highly recommend this novella and think any reader interested in Erotica at all will enjoy it.
